review.title: Exchangeable choice functions
review.abstract: We investigate how to model exchangeability with choice functions. Exchangeability is a structural assessment on a sequence of uncertain variables. We show how such assessments are a special indifference assessment, and how that leads to a counterpart of de Finetti's Representation Theorem, both in a finite and a countable context.

sections.text: ar Xiv: 170 3.01 924v 1 [cs.A I] 6 Mar 201 7Assessment using a sequence of uncertain variables. We show how such assessments are a special evaluation of indifference and how this leads to a counterpart to de Finetti's representation theorem, both in a finite and a countable context. Keywords: interchangeability; electoral functions; indifference; a series of desirable games of chance; representation.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: This work builds on the work on interchangeability for lower previsions (see de Cooman et al. (2009)) and interchangeability for sets of desirable games of chance (see de Cooman and Quaeghebeur (1972). Choice functions refer to the fundamental problem in decision theory: how to make a choice within a set of available options. In their book von Neumann and Morgenstern (1972) offer an axiomatization of choice based on pairing comparisons between options. Later, Rubin generalized this idea and proposed a theory of choice functions based on more than two elements. One of the aspects of Rubin's theory (1987) is that between each pair of options the agent either prefers one of them, or he is indifferent between them.

sections.heading: 4.2 Gambles of finite structure
sections.text: Before we can explain what it means to evaluate a countable sequence as interchangeable, we must recognize that there are now (countable) an infinite number of variables. However, from a behavioral point of view, we do not consider it useful to choose between games of chance that depend on an infinite number of variables. Since we will never know the actual outcome, games of chance will never really be paid out, and therefore any evaluation is essentially risk-free. Instead, we believe that it makes sense to consider only decisions between games of chance of finite structure: games that depend only on a finite number of variables. See De Bock et al. sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text: We have shown that interchangeability evaluation is a particular indifference evaluation in which we identified the set of indifferent options. The main idea that enabled a (finite) representation is the linear order of isomorphism H-1n between the quotient space and the set of games of chance on counter vectors, suggesting that (endless) interchangeable selection functions can be represented by an election function that essentially represents preferences between urns with n-spheres of type X with different compositions. Alternatively, in the countable case we have shown that there is a polynomial representation. Selection functions form a belief structure (see Van Camp et al. (2017)). Therefore, each infimum of coherent selection functions is a coherent choreography. As each infimum of selection functions is compatible with some fixed epics, I can well expect that the selection functions are (Van Camp) compatible.

We studied exchangeability and we have found counterparts to de Finetti’s finite and countable representation results, in the general setting of choice functions. We have shown that an exchangeability assessment is a particular indifference assessment, where we identified the set of indifferent options. The main idea that made (finite) representation possible is the linear order isomorphism H̃−1 n between the quotient space and the set of gambles on count vectors, indicating that (finitely) exchangeable choice functions can be represented by a choice function that essentially represents preferences between urns with n balls of types X with different compositions m. Alternatively, for the countable case, we have shown that there is a polynomial representation. Choice functions form a belief structure (see Van Camp et al. (2017)). Therefore, any infimum of coherent choice functions is a coherent choice function itself. Since any infimum of choice functions compatible with some fixed set of indifferent options I, is compatible with I as well (see Van Camp et al. (2017)), our results indicate that, using choice functions, it is conceptually easy to reason about exchangeable sequences: infima of exchangeable and coherent choice functions will be exchangeable and coherent as well.
It is shown, in de Cooman and Quaeghebeur (2012), that, for exchangeable sets of desirable gambles, updating can be done directly for the representing set of desirable gambles in the count space.
